title: Lennebergwald
text:
The Lennebergwald is a <a href="forest">forest</a> in the north of <a href="Rheinhessen">Rheinhessen</a> in <a href="Rhineland-Palatinate">Rhineland-Palatinate</a> in <a href="Germany">Germany</a>. The approximately 700 ha sized stretches north-west of <a href="Mainz">Mainz</a> between the urban districts of <a href="Mombach">Mombach</a>, <a href="Gonsenheim">Gonsenheim</a>, <a href="Finthen">Finthen</a> and the municipalities of <a href="Budenheim">Budenheim</a> and <a href="Heidesheim%20am%20Rhein">Heidesheim am Rhein</a> in the district of <a href="Mainz-Bingen">Mainz-Bingen</a>. Most of the area belongs to Budenheim.
Characteristic of the Lennebergwald is its dry and sandy soil, resulting in a high ground temperature during summer days. Due to this primarily <a href="pine">pine</a> and <a href="oak">oak</a> trees as well as dry and <a href="calcareous%20grassland">calcareous grassland</a> are growing here like in the neighbouring <a href="Mainz%20Sand%20Dunes">Mainz Sand Dunes</a>. The <a href="climate">climate</a> is <a href="temperate">temperate</a> and <a href="Semi-arid%20climate">semi-arid</a> to semi-humid.
Considering the aspect of <a href="ecology">ecology</a>, the Lenneberg forest has a high importance as a recreation area for people performing general fitness training such as <a href="jogging">jogging</a>, <a href="nordic%20walking">nordic walking</a>, <a href="mountainbiking">mountainbiking</a> as well as for people <a href="strolling">strolling</a> around the wooded area. Within the Lennebergwald some cultural heritage monuments of Budenheim, such as the old <a href="Wendelin%20of%20Trier">St.-Wendelinus</a>-chapel, the Lennebergtower (a look-out in <a href="Gothic%20Revival%20architecture">Gothic Revival architecture</a> comprising a stair tower, 1878–1880 by Philipp Johann Berdellé), the new St.-Wendelinus-chapel (Gothic Revival <a href="limestone">limestone</a> hall, 1862–1866) as well as the elevated water supply tanks of Budenheim (<a href="Art%20Nouveau">Art Nouveau</a> rotunda, erected 1907, by architect Wilhelm Lenz) and Gonsenheim (Art Nouveau building, 1909, also by Wilhelm Lenz).
